context_metadata.summary_text: The Clinical Negligence Report for patient John Doe, prepared by Dr. Sarah Thompson, outlines incidents of alleged medical negligence during his care at St. Mary's Hospital from February to May 2023. The report details a timeline of events beginning with an initial consultation on February 5, 2023, where Dr. Emily Harper diagnosed him with gastritis without further investigation. Subsequent visits revealed persistent symptoms, leading to a delayed ultrasound on March 15, which was postponed due to scheduling issues. The ultrasound, conducted on April 5, identified a large abdominal mass, but a referral to gastroenterology was not made until April 25 due to communication errors. Surgery was performed on May 2, but the patient suffered a post-surgical

The patient underwent surgery on May 2, 2023, to remove a mass, but mishandling of sterile equipment led to a post-operative infection, delaying recovery and worsening the patient's health. On May 15, the patient developed sepsis and required ICU admission due to the systemic response from the infection. Treatment with IV antibiotics stabilized the patient, but delays in diagnosis and treatment had significant negative effects on their health and quality of life. Key breaches of duty included failure to conduct necessary diagnostic tests, delays in scheduling imaging, inadequate post-surgical care, and communication failures between departments. These issues contributed to the patient's deteriorating condition, highlighting that early detection and proper surgical practices could have prevented the infection and its serious consequences.

episodes. • Associated Symptoms:  Bloating, gas, and occasional nausea. • Aggravating Factors:  Consumption of certain foods, stress. • Relieving Factors:  Resting, avoiding trigger foods. • Previous Episodes:  Similar episodes in the past, usually resolved without intervention. • Respiratory:  Clear to auscultation, no adventitious sounds. • Abdomen:  Soft, mild tenderness in the lower quadrants, no palpable masses. • Extremities:  No cyanosis, edema, or clubbing. • Neurological:  Cranial nerves II -XII intact, no focal deficits. Assessment:
